title: The English Revolution I: King and Parliament
summary: Introduces the 17th-century struggle between the English monarchy and Parliament, sowing the seeds of modern democracy.
utterances: Charles I’s rule without Parliament was unprecedented.
Financial and religious tensions pushed England to the brink.
The roadmap to revolution began with a budget crisis.
transcript: Mike Duncan explores the early conflicts between monarch and Parliament, and how these disputes laid the foundation for civil war.

title: The English Revolution II: Civil War Begins
summary: Describes the outbreak of the English Civil War, with Royalists and Parliamentarians facing off for the future of the nation.
utterances: The first shots divided an already fractious society.
Country and town allegiances seeded the conflict.
Early victories ebbed and flowed without clear winner.
transcript: Duncan traces the war’s initial battles, alliances, and shifting fortunes.

title: The English Revolution III: Trial and Execution
summary: Examines the trial of Charles I, his execution, and the unprecedented abolition of the monarchy.
utterances: The king’s trial was a world first.
Regicide shocked Europe and ended centuries of tradition.
England stumbled into republicanism.
transcript: Details events leading to the execution, the ripple effects on Europe, and the radical short-lived English Republic.

title: The English Revolution IV: Cromwell’s Republic
summary: Describes the experiment of republican government under Oliver Cromwell and how it unraveled.
utterances: Puritan governance left little room for dissent.
Cromwell’s victories couldn’t solve all England’s ills.
Republican dreams dissolved back into monarchy.
transcript: Focuses on the rise and fall of Cromwell, and the restoration of monarchy after his death.

title: Prelude to the American Revolution
summary: Shifts focus to colonial America—reviewing the social, political, and economic forces that set the stage for rebellion.
utterances: Colonial grievances built over years.
The Seven Years' War created debt—and new taxes.
British policy set the stage for revolutionary thought.
transcript: Duncan transitions from England to the American colonies, explaining why rebellion fermented.

title: The Road to Independence
summary: Traces the escalation from protests and pamphlets to first open acts of war against Britain.
utterances: No taxation without representation became a rally cry.
Boston became the heart of resistance.
Armed conflict was not inevitable—until it was.
transcript: Outlines major milestones: Stamp Act, Boston Tea Party, and moves toward formal rebellion.

title: Lexington to Yorktown
summary: Describes the military course of the American Revolution, the alliances, key figures, and shifting fortunes of war.
utterances: Minutemen became legends after Lexington.
Washington’s leadership developed by trial and error.
French help was a turning point.
transcript: Analyzes key battles, leaders, and the often-overlooked complexities of revolutionary strategy.

title: Building the American Republic
summary: Examines the drafting of founding documents and the challenges of uniting the new nation post-independence.
utterances: The Articles of Confederation created more problems than they solved.
Compromise built the Constitution’s foundations.
Revolution forced Americans to rethink power.
transcript: Focuses on Constitutional debates and early test cases for the new republic.

title: Prelude to the French Revolution
summary: Surveys 18th-century France—financial crises, class differences, and the Enlightenment’s impact on revolutionary thinking.
utterances: Bourbon monarchy faced growing debts and unrest.
Philosophers stirred political change.
Revolution was more likely than anyone realized.
transcript: Sets the stage for social and political explosion in pre-revolutionary France.

title: The Estates-General and the Storming of the Bastille
summary: Recounts the summoning of the Estates-General and the dramatic opening attacks that sparked the French Revolution.
utterances: The Bastille fell in a single, symbolic day.
Political chaos followed quickly.
Revolutionary fever spread through Paris.
transcript: Highlights the iconic opening moments and immediate consequences for French society.

title: Declaration of the Rights of Man
summary: Focuses on the drafting, meaning, and global legacy of the Declaration of the Rights of Man and Citizen.
utterances: The Rights of Man changed world politics.
Its writers drew heavily on Enlightenment ideas.
Contradictions appeared almost immediately.
transcript: Describes debates in the National Assembly and early tensions in guaranteeing rights in practice.

title: Flight to Varennes: The King Runs
summary: Describes Louis XVI’s failed escape attempt, and how it radicalized the revolution.
utterances: The king’s flight destroyed royalist credibility.
Paris’ population felt newly empowered.
The shift to radicalism was now inevitable.
transcript: Explores the fallout from the king’s desertion and increased demands for a republic.

title: 1792: War and the Monarchy’s Collapse
summary: Reviews the wars with Austria and Prussia, the dethroning of Louis XVI, and the events leading to the Republic’s proclamation.
utterances: Foreign threats unified France—then radicalized it.
The king was deposed as enemies closed in.
Revolution spread beyond Paris.
transcript: Examines military and street fighting that forced the monarchy’s end.

title: Reign of Terror
summary: Analyzes Robespierre’s rise, the guillotine’s reign, and how revolutionary paranoia spiraled into mass executions.
utterances: The guillotine became a symbol of the revolution.
Robespierre’s vision morphed into terror.
Fear consumed both friend and foe alike.
transcript: Highlights revolutionary tribunals, shifting leadership, and cultural ramifications of the Terror.

title: The Directory: From Chaos to Napoleon
summary: Explains how post-Terror French government tried to establish stability, and how rising general Napoleon took power.
utterances: Post-Terror France was as unstable as ever.
Corruption and coups dominated the Directory.
Napoleon’s ascent was stealthy—and sudden.
transcript: Duncan details the political chaos, failed reforms, and the constitutional changes that set the stage for Napoleonic France.

title: Haitian Revolution: Slaves and Empire
summary: Turns to the world-changing Haitian Revolution, focusing on the impact of slaves, planters, and French empire.
utterances: Saint-Domingue became the world’s most brutal and lucrative colony.
Free people of color played pivotal roles.
Slave uprising changed the continent’s fate.
transcript: Unpacks the economic, social, and global context of the only successful slave revolt in modern history.

title: Toussaint Louverture: Hero and Rebel
summary: Focuses on Toussaint Louverture, who steered the Haitian Revolution into a global force.
utterances: Toussaint turned slavery upside down.
The revolution’s leaders were complex and divided.
European powers underestimated him at their peril.
transcript: Covers Toussaint’s early rise, diplomatic genius, military victories, and the beginning of the republic.

title: Haiti’s Fight for Independence
summary: Covers battles against France, Britain, and internal rivals, leading to the proclamation of Haiti as a free republic.
utterances: Foreign invaders threatened the fragile new nation.
The revolutionaries’ unity was always shaky.
Haiti’s independence set a precedent for the Americas.
transcript: Details the final campaigns, independence, and Haiti’s place in world history.

title: Prelude to the Spanish American Wars
summary: Switches to Latin America—the colonial structures, social hierarchies, and new ideas that bred rebellion.
utterances: Spanish colonies were boiling with tension.
The success of Haiti and the US inspired change.
Creoles looked for their own place in history.
transcript: Reveals the broad context, international politics, and why Spanish America was ripe for revolution.

title: Bolívar and the Liberators
summary: Introduces Simón Bolívar and other key leaders, explaining how the Latin American revolutions began.
utterances: Bolívar was as much myth as man.
Liberation swept across the continent in waves.
No single revolution fits the Latin American template.
transcript: First battles, alliances, and how disparate movements moved toward a common goal.
